Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Comprehensive Theoretical Study of Cosmic Magnetic Fields, their Origin, Evolution, and Signatures
Award.AbstractNarration:
People use a compass to learn their direction of travel. Such a compass works because its tiny magnetic needle aligns with the magnetic field of Earth and indicates the direction of North. On scales much larger than Earth, our own Milky Way Galaxy also has its own magnetic field. In fact, all galaxies in the Universe appear to have magnetic fields, and these magnetic fields can have profound effects on a galaxy's development throughout its lifetime. Through a series of sophisticated computer simulations, this project aims to unlock the puzzling origin of the magnetic fields found in galaxies. Upon completion this project might point to an origin of these magnetic fields that coincides with the birth of the Universe itself. Such a result could have a profound influence on our current understanding of fundamental physics, and its pursuit serves the national interest of developing US scientific leadership in astrophysics. This project will also strengthen the US science workforce by directly training undergraduate and graduate students in general and computational astrophysics. Project plans also include a vigorous education and public outreach program.

More technically, observations show that galaxies have magnetic fields with a component that is coherent over a large fraction of the galaxy with field strengths of order microgauss. These fields are assumed to be from the amplification of initial weak seed magnetic fields of unknown nature. The two scenarios of their origin are (1) a bottom-up astrophysical one, where the needed seed field is generated on smaller scales and (2) a top-down cosmological scenario where the seed field is generated prior to galaxy formation in the early Universe on scales that are large now. Based on current observations, this project aims to distinguish between these two scenarios. To achieve this goal, the evolution and observational signatures of cosmic magnetic fields will be studied in different astrophysical environments such as clusters, galaxies, and interstellar medium. Numerical simulations will model the evolution of cosmic magnetic fields in the expanding Universe with time varying dissipative properties when initial conditions correspond to the different scenarios of the magnetogenesis. This project is divided into the following related parts: (i) theoretical studies of magnetogenesis mechanisms including the cosmological and astrophysical scenarios; (ii) numerical simulations of large-scale magnetic fields evolution to analyze whether astrophysical mechanisms can lead to extragalactic magnetic field strengths comparable with the lower bounds; and (iii) determining potentially observable signatures of cosmic magnetic fields coherent at large scales---including cosmic structure formation, microwave background fluctuations, or ultra high energy gamma-ray propagation. The project will search for signatures of primordial cosmic magnetic fields that distinguish cosmological seeds from astrophysical sources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is commonly assumed that observed cosmic magnetic fields are the result of amplification of initial weak seed fields of unknown nature. Currently two basic scenarios of seed magnetic field generation are widely considered: a astrophysical scenario, where the seed is typically very weak and magnetic field is transferred from local sources within galaxies to larger scales, and a cosmological scenario where a significant seed field is generated prior to galaxy formation in the early universe on scales that are large now. Observations of blazar's spectra indicate the possible presence of large-scale magnetic fields in cosmic voids that is challenging to be explained through astrophysical scenarios, and favors the primordial origin of the large-scale magnetic fields in the universe.  Our major goal was to distinguish between these two scenarios. For this purpose we have performed an interdisciplinary research that includes i) theoretical studies of primordial magnetogenesis mechanisms; (ii) direct numerical simulations (DNS) of the primordial magnetic field evolution during different epochs of the universe expansion, starting from the moment of the magnetic field evolution till the present epoch; iii) development of magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) turbulence in the primordial plasma, and associated effects, such as decay and amplification of MHD turbulence and generation of kinetic motions of plasma; iv) investigation of chiral magnetic effect in the early universe and DNS-based modeling of the turbulent chiral-magnetic cascade;  (v) comparison of the outcome magnetic field strengths with the lower bounds of the large-scale magnetic fields imposed through the blazar?s spectra observations by FERMI and VERITAS collaborations; (vi) investigation of observable signatures of primordial magnetic fields and MHD turbulence, including cosmic microwave background fluctuations and gravitational waves; (vii) DNS of MHD turbulence in interstellar medium (ISM) in order to better understand turbulence in Milky Way Galaxy and the Galactic microwave background polarization.    

The interdisciplinary nature of our research have led to the results having implications in  various fields. In particular, outcomes of our studies are not limited to theoretical astrophysics, but also include important parts related to high-energy physics: chiral magnetic effect (see outcomes-1), parity-symmetry violations in the early universe and testing the duration of inflation (see outcomes-2), DNS of MHD processes: decay (see outcomes-3), amplification through the dynamo effect (see outcomes-4) in the early universe, gravitational waves physics (generation of gravitational waves through turbulence and magnetic fields; direct detection prospects, see outcomes-5), data analysis (lower and upper bounds for the large-scale magnetic fields, see outcomes-6), programming and software development (the Pencil code modules for the MHD turbulence development and evolution, the chiral magnetic effect in the early universe, the Galactic polarization, and the gravitational wave signal). 

We are pleased to report on the success of our collaboration: we have significantly improved the current understanding of primordial magnetogenesis, we have made an advancement in the modeling physical processes in the early universe plasma, and we have made several theoretical predictions for future missions such as observations of the cosmic microwave background parity?odd polarization anisotropies, and the gravitational wave signal potentially detectable through Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA).  

Apart from the conferences and publications in highly ranked journals, the results of our research are used as a teaching material for advanced courses and summer schools, allowing young researchers to start working with and on the newly developed techniques and insights. The most important results are included into university courses taught by the project?s main participants. Notably, two Ph.d. thesis (Sayan Mandal and Alberto Roper Pol) projects were designed, performed, and are expected in the framework of the project.

PI and the research team members (including students involved in the project) have participated in a number of national and international conferences, workshops, and symposia (such as 12th International LISA symposium, 29th TEXAS 2017 symposium on Relativistic Astrophysics, The XXX IAU General Assembly,  PHENO 2017, 2018, and 2019), and have delivered presentations. A number of invited talks were given at different institutions. PIs have organized the NORDITA 2019 4weeks program (including workshop and conference), entitled "Gravitational Waves from the Early Universe", at which the results of our research were widely covered.

Dissemination of the project results included not only scientific community, but much wider public as well. This is primarily aimed towards educational purposes. The educational aspects of the project include the training of the undergraduate and graduate students (including four female students). There were a number of public and educational lectures delivered by PI and other participants, as well as other outreach efforts to local high and middle school students (in particular, Carnegie Mellon Physics Department's CONCEPTS program). In addition, PI and the project outreach coordinator organized and participated in different outreach activities including those through Carnegie Science Center, such as Cafe Scientifique, Girls Rock Science, SciTech Workshops, Astronomy Day and a new program, "Two Scientists Walk into a Bar", and others.
